docs.lead_paragraph: Writers of memoirs from Casanova to B.@F. Skinner have pondered the pleasures of smoking. The Italian adventurer reported that the sight of the smoke was a great part of the enjoyment, offering as evidence his own observations that the blind did not smoke and that smokers avoided smoking in the dark. Some two centuries later, the American psychologist concurred: Darkness prevented the pipe smoker from being able to judge the state of the fire in the bowl by the density of smoke in the air. Scientists have been trying to identify what ancillary pleasure might be responsible for keeping people hooked on smoking, since nicotine itself does not produce clear-cut addictive behavior in laboratory tests. They suspect that nicotine enhances some associated sensation in the smoking experience, perhaps taste, and that once such a connection is established, nicotine becomes its own reward. A recent report in the journal Science suggests that nicotine functioned in precisely this way for four squirrel monkeys taking the drug intravenously.
